A. Country Background
1. Afghanistan has achieved much in the three years since December 2001 when the Afghanistan Interim Administration (AIA) was inaugurated in Kabul. Picking up the reins o f governance at that point the AIA was confronted with an economy reeling from protracted conflict and drought, more than five million people displaced as refugees in neighboring countries, economic activities steered in an informal or illicit direction by insecurity, and a state that had become virtually non functional in terms of policy making and service delivery - although the structures and many staff remained. The achievements that have been made subsequently are significant, and inAfghanistan's context, remarkable.
2. Afghanistan's economy has performed strongly in the past two and half years with non- drug Gross Domestic Product (GDP) reaching US$ 4.6 billion in 2003/04 (corresponding to a GDP per capita o f about US$200 per year), an increase o f almost 50 percent, albeit from a very low base. This is mainly attributable to the recovery o f agriculture from the drought, revival o f economic activities after major conflict ended, and the commencement o f reconstruction efforts. This solid performance has been supported by the Government's sound macroeconomic policies -ahighlysuccessfulcurrencyreforminlate2002,aprudentnooverdraftpolicyprohibiting domestic financing o f the budget deficit, conservative monetary policy, and good management o f the exchange rate. Progress has been made in mobilizing domestic resources as well as donor assistance in support o f the Government's medium-term development program, with expenditures financed by external assistance increased to more than US$ 2 billion in 2003/04. The Government has also made considerable progress in formulating the budget and developing a medium-term expenditure framework.
3. These achievements notwithstanding, the challenges remain enormous in improving security throughout the country, reestablishing national unity, developing institutions with a capacity to formulate and implement policies, reaching out to provinces to collect revenues and deliver services, and implementing the Government's long-term vision for the future o f Afghanistan.
B. Government Economic Management Strategy
4. Following its inauguration, the Government quickly took the initiative in formulating Afghanistan's development strategy. InApril 2002, it formulated a comprehensive development strategy -the National Development Framework (NDF) -which outlined a strong agenda to rebuild institutions and implement structural reforms within a stable macroeconomic framework. The NDF was also a significant step in underpinning a truly Government-led reconstruction process. The NDF provides a framework to coordinate the Government's programs and donor assistance and also provides the basis for preparingthe National Budget.
5. The NDF was further underpinned by a report released by the Government in March 2004: Securing Afghanistan's Future: Accomplishments and the Strategic Path Forward (SAF).
1  SAF' sets out a comprehensive framework and investment program based on outcome targets to be achieved in 2015 to align with the Millennium Development Goals Framework. It provides an assessment o f the investment and recurrent cost requirement over a seven-year horizon, identifying a requirement for external assistance inthe range o f US$ 27 billion over this period. The report provided the basis for a major donor meeting heldinBerlin inMarch 2004 where the international community pledged US$ 8.2 billion for reconstruction and security activities over the next three years (SYl383-1385), with US$4.4 billion pledgedfor SY1383 alone.
6. These strategy documents have as their core the principle o f a well-functioning state that i s accountable to its citizens and able to ensure the delivery o f services in an equitable, efficient, and effective manner. The Government's objective o f providing an enabling environment for growth requires an effective central government that can reestablish national unity on the basis o f strong institutions and the rule of law. The SAF report laid out a vision inthe area o f economic management (box 1) and several specific goals, including:
0 A well-functioning and well structured security sector based on institutions that facilitate a return to normalcy inthe political, economic, and social spheres;
0 An effective public administration that is small and focused on core functions; more diverse and decentralized; better skilled, equipped and managed; more accountable; and more representative interms o f gender and ethnicity; and
0 A budget that is affordable and sustainable on a multi-year basis. and enables delegation o f authority based on strong accountability mechanisms.

9. All of these efforts are expected to result in an expansion of absorptive capacity consistent with the experience inother post-conflict countries which has shown that the capacity to absorb development assistanceincreasesdramatically after approximately three years.
11. IDARESPONSE
A. Bank's Transitional Support Strategy
10. The reconstruction strategy developed by the Government of Afghanistan forms the framework within which the Bank's Transitional Support Strategy (TSS) has been prepared. Approved in March 2003, the TSS sets out priorities for Bank financial and non-financial assistance based on the areas o f comparative advantage of the Bank and the particular situation in Afghanistan. The TSS focuses on four strategic areas: (a) improving livelihoods; (b) strengthening the fiscal strategy, institutions andmanagement; (c) implementinggovernance and public administration reform; and (d) enabling private sector development.
3  B. Rationalefor IDA'sInvolvementinPublicAdministrationandEconomicManagement
11. Both the first and second TSS for Afghanistan emphasizedthe need for Afghans to be in the "driver's seat" with regard to managing the reconstruction and development process. Under the Government's steadfast direction, donors have increasingly supported Government programs and accepted the budget as the instrument for managing donor resources. In parallel, the Government has had to demonstrate its ability to manage resources in an effective and transparent manner, with an increasing emphasis on rules-based economic governance and effective capacity building.
12. Within the governance and public administration reform strategic areas, the Bank's strategy has been to identify pragmatic opportunities for action inthe short term, initiating a set of immediate reforms which would be supportive of longer-term improvements in public administration. It.has entailed: (a) ensuringthat emergency capacity i s inplace, especially inkey fiduciary areas, while launching medium-term capacity building efforts; (b) undertaking extensive diagnostic work along with ongoing technical and policy advice to identify and address key constraints; (c) identifying short-term goals that are fully owned by the Government and agreedwith all major donors; and (d) providinggap financing whenneeded.
13. The First and Second Emergency Public Administration Projects (EPAP Iand 11) primarily supported the first and second prongs of the above strategy. Other Bank instruments, including analytical work and policy dialogue in administrative reform, as well as the Programmatic Support for Institution Building (PSIB) adjustment operation, have supported the thirdand fourthprongs.
14. This strategy initially focused on achieving progress in governance and public administration reform through quick-wins, and in ways that did not undermine medium-term goals. As the Bank has engaged in an increasingly substantive policy dialogue with the Government in the area of administrative reform, a progressive shift has been made toward supporting medium-term solutions to build capacity within Government, including: (a) supporting broader public expenditure legislative reform agenda covering budget, procurement, and audit laws; (b) strengthening sub-national governance through the Afghanistan Stabilization Programme; (c) rationalizing ministries through the PRR process; (d) reforming pay and payroll systems; and (e) strengthening financial control, reporting, audit, and procurement systems.
C. The First and Second EmergencyPublicAdministrationProjects
15. EPAP Iwas IDA's first operation in Afghanistan and totaled US$ 10 million. It was approved in April 2002 and became effective in June 2002. The objective of the project was to put inplace emergency capacity inkey public administration areas to facilitate the use of donor and own resources for urgent reconstruction and development efforts. It also aimed to support some basic steps toward building a transparent, well-functioning public administration. EPAP I was comprised of three components:
e Procurement Strengthening Component to support the transparent and efficient utilizationof donor resourcesthrough employment of a procurement agent;
4  0 Treasury DepartmentStrengtheningComponentto kick start the budget execution and expenditure accounting and reporting functions through employment of an international financial management agent; and
0 Audit Capacity Strengthening Component to ensure the timely audit o f Government expenditure through engagement o f an Audit Agent.
16. In June 2003 a follow-up project (Second Emergency Public Administration Project, EPAP 11) was approved. EPAP I1provided supplemental financing for the procurement and financial management contracts supported under EPAP I.EPAP I1also provided funds for the Government's Public Administration Reform program (PAR), implemented by the Independent Administrative Reform and Civil Service Commission (IARCSC) andjointly financed with the Department for International Development (DFID). These funds support activities to strengthen the functions o f the IARCSC inimplementing the PRRprocess and other priority activities inthe PARprogram.
17. EPAP Iand I1have been core elements o f IDA's first and second TSSs, providing the underpinning fiduciary arrangements for the entire IDA portfolio. This enabled IDA to reactivate operations with Afghanistan very quickly in the post-conflict period. In addition, IDA's early support in these areas enabled the Government to quickly build credibility with donors as to their ability to effectively manage donor and own resource. This i s reflected inthe increasing numbers o f donors prepared to channel funds either directly through the Treasury or via the Afghanistan Reconstruction Trust Fund (ARTF). EPAP I1 has also enabled the Government to lay the basis for reforming the administrative arrangements within government.
18. A mid-term review was conducted of EPAP Iand EPAP I1in early 2004. The review concluded that the projects had made significant progress in achieving their objectives (box 3) particularly in the context o f Afghanistan's extremely limited capacity and engagement with the international community over the past twenty years. Early assistance focused on the provision o f emergency capacity in critical fiduciary areas. Because o f the emergency nature o f this assistance, broader institutional development and capacity building activities did not proceed as quickly as expectations in this regard. In some areas, the lack o f a medium-term framework for systems development, regulatory reform, and capacity building inhibited further progress being made, particularly inexpanding the activities to line ministries and provinces.
Box 3. Key Achievements under EPAP Iand I1 As o f mid-November 2004, the Afghanistan Reconstruction Development Services (ARDS) has processed 202 contracts with a value of USD 392.9m with a further 42 contracts in preparation estimated at USD 257m. A draft procurement law has been prepared and between 110 and 150 procurement staff from line ministries have receivedtraining inbasic and specific procurement rules. In the Treasury, a functioning computerized general ledger and payments system is in place with some networking o f components; significant improvements have been made in cash management, grant management, bankreconciliations, revenue recording, and the recording of budget appropriations and allotments. The Auditor General has completed the audits o f the financial statements o f ARTF, the state budget, and an increasing number o f IDA and ARTF-funded projects.
19. The mid-term review concludedthat continued operational assistance would be necessary to maintain standards o f fiduciary control for the near term, and in order to maintain donor
5  confidence in the Government's fiduciary mechanisms. At the same time, the Government considers it crucial to transition from "buying-in" capacity to developing it within Government within a clearly articulated medium-term development framework. Inresponse to this, IDA and the Government have had extensive dialogue during the last six months on a coherent medium- term public expenditure management reform and capacity building strategy that addresses legislative, regulatory, and institutional reforms and development o f management control systems and HR. The Government has requested IDA assistance inthe implementation o f such a strategy. The proposedproject i s prepared inthis context.
111. THEPROPOSEDPROJECT
A. ProjectObjective
20. The overall objective o f the project i s to assist the authorities in developing the capacity to manage public expenditures in an effective, transparent, and accountable manner in order to achieve satisfactory and sustainable development outcomes in Afghanistan. The project will have a particular focus on enhancing the performance o f public sector procurement, financial management, and accountability systems.
21. Success inmeetingthe project's objective will be measured by:
0 Establishment and implementation o f sound regulatory and control frameworks for budget execution and fiscal reporting, andpublic sector procurement;
0 Further development o f core systems for budget execution, Government accounting, andinternaland externalaudits;
0 Development o f HRto effectively manage and operate these critical systems; and
0 Operational performance (technical efficiency) o f the fiduciary management functions.
B. ProjectApproach
22. The proposed project combines technical assistance (TA) for continued operational support in core fiduciary functions with assistance for implementation of legislative, regulatory, and institutional reforms; systems development; and HR development. The project will reflect the lessons learned in the first two projects by putting into effect a clear capacity building strategy ineach area based upon the following:
0 Ensuring capacity building activities are firmly grounded ina medium-termstrategic planfor development o f the core functions withinGovernment;
0 Facilitating the long-term sustainability o f capacity buildingthrough establishment o f an appropriate legal, regulatory, and control environment;
0 Ensuringthat further systems development is based on a medium-term approach to requirements and a full understandingo f local conditions and capabilities;
6  Ensuringthat key functions are defined and established not only in the core central agencies but also inthe line ministries;
Ensuringcounterpart staff are inplace inthese core functional areas so that effective knowledge transfer can take place;
Ensuring terms o f reference for technical assistance service providers accord adequate consideration to on-the-job training and knowledge transfer with key milestones identified inorder to monitor progress; and
Separating major training activities from the delivery o f operational support consultancy services to maximize value-for-money and to avoid the risk that urgent operational support objectives will crowd out essential capacity building activities.
23. The Government wishes to examine options for bringing about many o f the necessary institutional improvements in public expenditure management, where possible, through relationships (twinning) with experienced and well-performing institutions/agencies in other countries. Twinning with experienced entities in the core functional areas may provide opportunities to integrate know-how transfer and on-the-job staff training. Twinningalso has the advantage o f sensitizing Government staff to an experienced well-functioning organization, a dimension that consultancy assignments often lack. The Government has requested that the various TA components under the project be examined for the degree to which twinning arrangements could be utilized for some activities, particularly those related to strategic development and capacity building. This approach does not preclude the need for separate contracting o f operational or specific tasks where appropriate.
C. Project Description
24. Inpursuit ofthese objectives, the project is comprisedoffive components:
Component 1: Strengthening Procurement Capacity within Government (US$9,000,000)
25. Under the Procurement Strengthening Component o f the EPAP Iand 11, a central Procurement Agent was contracted to put in place emergency procurement capacity to facilitate rapid, transparent utilization o f donor resources for reconstruction and development. This component was implemented by the Afghanistan Assistance Coordination Authority (AACA) and subsequently by the ARDS.
26. The EPAP mid-term review recognized that the provision o f emergency centralized procurement capacity was essential early on in Afghanistan's reconstruction effort. It also concluded that there would be a continued need for centralized procurement services for some time. However, the Government now wishes to see an accelerated effort to build procurement capacity within line ministries to enable them to perform key procurement functions to adequate standards. This is also critical for improving eligibility levels under the recurrent cost component o f the ARTF. This will require focused assistance in capacity building, organizational reform, and legal/regulatory development.
7  27. This component of the project will provide technical advisory support, equipment, and training to the ARDS Procurement Unit and a nascent Procurement Policy Unit (PPU) in order to:
A. Support line ministrieswith the direct procurement process, particularly in relation to donor programs, for the next three years through a consultancy contract with a procurement facilitation firm. An allowance i s included to cover operating costs o f the Procurement Unit within the ARDS through June 2005 when it i s expected that the costs will be met by the Government.
B. Undertake a procurement capacity building program within line ministries so that they can progressively be accredited with increased delegated authority for procurement management within an agreed institutional and legal framework. This program (which will include activities to promote Afghan private sector participation in procurement) will not only focus on central ministries but will also reach out to staff in provinces, districts, and municipalities. The capacity building program will include programs to: (i)train staff and implement a coherent certification system; (ii)strengthen the procurement function within Government through the PRR process; and (iii)transfer procurement responsibility to line ministriesaccordingto a series o fperformance milestones.
C. Support the promulgation and implementation o f the new procurement law and regulations and establishment o f a PPUwithin Government.
28. The Government has already issued a contract to a consulting firm, Rites o f India, for the assistance set out insubcomponent 1(A).

The Government has begun a program o f financial management improvement which i s expected to have far-reaching consequences for the manner and processes o f financial transactions, recording, accounting, and reporting over the next several years. The extent o f these reforms is evolving but includes budget and expenditure reforms and improved accounting, financial reporting, and internal controls. The Government has drafted a new Public Finance and Expenditure Management Law which i s expected to be approved before parliamentary elections in the middle of 2005 (this approval is a trigger for the second Programmatic Support for Institution Buildingoperation).
30. Component 3: Strengthening Internal Audit Capacity within Government (US$4,000,000)
34. The mid-termreview identified the lack of an effective internal audit function as a critical constraint to improving public expenditure management within Government. There are currently designated internal audit departments operating in key line ministries that report directly to their
9  ministers. They do not carry out work that would be considered to comply with recognized international internal auditing standards. Audit work i s currently focused on the identificationof irregularities and the investigation of potential corruption and fraud. No reviews of internal control processesare carried out.
35. This component will provide technical advisory services, training, and equipment to support the internal audit function within Government. The establishment of an effective internal audit service, following generally recognized international standards of internal auditing and control, will help to improve public sector accountability and governance. The CAO audits the FinalAccount of the MOF and also undertakes external audits inthe provinces.

A range of training activities, both formal (including training in English, computer literacy, and basic accounting) and on-the-job training through the conduct of audits, have been conducted with more than 100 CAO staff taking part. Inaddition, an audit law has been drafted as well as a draft strategic plan.
39. These early steps have been successful inreestablishingthe CAO as a working institution but have not developed the institution and its staff sufficiently for them to conduct financial

A. ImplementationArrangements

doc.repnme: Afghanistan - Public Administration Capacity Building Project
doc.abstracts: The Public Administration Capacity Building Project for Afghanistan aims to assist the authorities in developing the capacity to manage public expenditures in an effective, transparent, and accountable manner in order to achieve satisfactory and sustainable development outcomes in Afghanistan. The project will have a particular focus on enhancing the performance of public sector procurement, financial management, and accountability systems. Success in meeting the project's objective will be measured by: establishment and implementation of sound regulatory and control frameworks for budget execution and fiscal reporting, and public sector procurement; further development of core systems for budget execution, government accounting, and internal and external audits; development of HR to effectively manage and operate these critical systems; and operational performance (technical efficiency) of the fiduciary management functions.
